text: asked the Minister for National Development with the recent announcement of the three enhancements to HDB's upgrading programmes (a) whether the Ministry plans to increase the budget to enable more flats that qualify, to benefit sooner from the Home Improvement Programme (HIP), Neighbourhood Renewal Programme (NRP) and Selective Lift Replacement Programme (SLRP) each year; and (b) what is the timeline for the upgrading works to be completed for the new batch of flats that qualify.
Madam, the three enhancements are significant and will further improve the living environment in existing HDB towns. They will allow more residents to enjoy the benefits of upgrading.

They will impose additional cost on the Government. For example, the NRP cost cap will be raised from $3,400 to $4,700 per flat, to pay for the additional works. The SLRP will require the Government to fund 50% of the lift replacement cost, up to a cap of $125,000 per lift. We will set aside sufficient budget to fund all these enhancements.

HDB expects to complete the selection of all eligible flats for HIP by 2018. As for NRP and SLRP, their implementation will largely be by the local Town Councils. NRP will also require the active engagement of residents in shaping their living environment. The pace of implementation will therefore depend on the extent of active local participation.

I thank the Minister for his response. I am glad that these programmes are in place. I know many of my residents in Chua Chu Kang are certainly very happy and excited by this development. On the question of timeline, I understand the Minister said that this would depend on the Town Councils and the level of engagement on the ground. At the same time, for each Town Council, we are given a quota in terms of the number of projects we can set aside each year. With the new number of blocks that are qualifying now, would that mean that the number of projects we can do per year also increases, if we can show that we can engage more on the ground at the same time?

The second question is the announcement that the Minister made yesterday in terms of some of the new developments in technologies for LUP. Given that we are doing Selective LRP on some of these estates that previously could not benefit from LUP, will there be any possibility of dove-tailing the two sides? Once you have upgraded the blocks, you may actually discount them from undergoing LUP in future.

Madam, indeed, we are ramping up the pace of the development. There are three different projects here. For HIP, we are increasing it rapidly. For the HIP, the potential universe is about 300,000 flats. Today, we have started doing -- and some have been completed – about 140,000. This is almost the midway point, maybe about the 45%-mark. I am stepping up the pace of HIP so that over the next two years, we should be able to launch 100,000 flats. The remaining would be about 60,000 flats left. We are very confident that the entire HIP can be wrapped up during the next term of government.

I remember Senior Minister of State Masagos Zulkifli gave me this advice. He said, "These are very old flats, and sometimes, they already have spalling concrete, leakages and so on". The flat owners were debating whether to do the repairs themselves or to wait for HIP. Taking his advice, we decided that starting from early next year, we will announce the selected projects for two years in one go. That means 100,000 flats will be nominated and decided upon. In fact, our circular has already gone out a few weeks ago to the Town Councils. Please think through carefully, which are the important blocks that are urgently in need, and then, we will try to pace them in accordance to needs. That is for HIP.

For NRP, I am prepared to do faster and to do more, but Town Councils have a problem. And that is why for several years, we have settled at the pace of about one project per year per Town Council. They find that if there are more than one NRP projects, they have indigestion. If Chua Chu Kang Town Council can do better, you are most welcome. Nominate them and I am game to match your pace. But I think you will find difficulty because it is a project where the emphasis is on consultation as you want the locals to own the project. So, they need to gather to discuss, "What shall we have? More drop-off points and so on?" That process of engagement, you cannot rush it.

As for the LRP, it is a very specialised item. In fact, it was the Member who alerted this House to the lifts that he has in Chua Chu Kang which did not seem to be as good as some of the lifts that he had seen in the newer blocks. We probed and found that there were about 700 such lifts. For some reason, most of them were installed in his GRC, as well as in Pasir Ris. Together, they "cornered" the market!

That particular model of lifts, in due course, would be replaced with new and better model. When you need to replace them, we will fund half of the cost, which is quite substantial because the cost of a lift is about a quarter million dollars. It will cost the Government almost $100 million. Again, this is where we leave it to you to decide when you want to replace them. When you do replace them, send us the bill and we will co-pay part of the cost. But do not waste. Although those lifts are a bit "funny", they are functional. Actually, they are not "funny" at all; they are totally functional and safe. But if you feel that you prefer some of the new features of the new lifts and you want them now, instead of waiting for the full 28 years life-span of the lifts, and they are maybe at Year 25, you may want to advance doing it. If you decide to do it, send us the bill and we will pay half of it.

asked  the Minister for National Development (a) whether it is acceptable for newly installed lift frames under the HDB Lift Upgrading Programme to be rusty; (b) who is responsible for the quality of materials used in a Lift Upgrading Programme; and (c) whether equal standards of materials used, such as those for lift frames, are applied across all Lift Upgrading Programmes.

Madam, all the stainless steel parts used in lift frames must meet HDB's specifications. HDB requires contractors to submit a material testing report on the type of stainless steel grade used. HDB also conducts audit checks on the lift material used.

The completed lift works are handed over to Town Councils for maintenance. Stainless steel parts need to be maintained regularly to preserve its corrosion resistance. HDB has shared with the Town Councils (TCs) the need for a regular maintenance regime for the lifts and its stainless steel parts. HDB has also conducted demonstrations to the TCs and their maintenance contractors. Many of the lifts island-wide where TCs have regular maintenance regimes are in good condition. We will continue to work with the TCs to ensure that the maintenance contractors comply with the maintenance regime.
Ms Tin Pei Ling.

Thank you, Madam. I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State about the particular lift upgrading in MacPherson. I am referring in particular to Block 121, Paya Lebar Way. I have raised this for more than a year with the HDB officer. Basically, shortly after installation and before it was handed over to Town Council, there was a survey. During that survey, it was noted that there was already rust formed on the lift frame or the door jamb, but because we did not want to delay the commission of the lift, so as to provide convenience to the residents, the Town Council took over and decided to run with it.

But my point of contention is that the lift is the main product of a Lift Upgrading project. In this case, if the lift frame came with rust on it, should it be accepted? In this case, while HDB has demonstrated on how to maintain the lift frame, the cost – in terms of manpower and material cost – is considerable, added up over time. Would this be fair to the Town Council who has to inherit this from HDB?

The third question that I would like to ask is whether the material used for this particular lift upgrading is similar to the kind of materials used for the other LUPs across the island. If it is not the same, why so? Is it something that we should accept?

Madam, let me thank the Member for her questions. There are many grades of stainless steel. They are used in different environments. Among different grade, stainless steel has a common characteristic – they are corrosion resistant, but not corrosion proof. Depending on the grade used, they all need to be maintained. Maintenance in this case for the lift frames would mean using washing detergent, and sometimes, certain chemicals to wipe the frames. The frequency required would be about once a month. In the high usage areas where the lift frames are likely to come into contact with chloride ions, meaning salt or sweat, then, those parts would need to be maintained more often.

Since 2005, HDB has specified the stainless steel grade 430 to be used. This is applied in all the Lift Upgrading Programme projects plus new lift installations island-wide for the next seven years or so. It is not just specific in MacPherson area. Over the island, there are 8,000 such lifts and their frames being installed.

Having learnt from the feedback from the various Town Councils, HDB has since 2012, switched to a higher grade of stainless steel, that is stainless steel grade 304. That has reduced the frequency for maintenance but it does not eliminate maintenance altogether. It still requires maintenance that will remove what would look like coffee stains on the lift frames.

I thank the Member for her patience and her Town Council's, for working with HDB. They are, together, looking for other ways, for example, applying certain coatings that may reduce the maintenance frequency and extend the life and appearance of the lift frames.
Er Dr Lee Bee Wah.

Thank you, Mdm Speaker. As far as I know, in the construction industry, when the client has a budget, the consultant or the architect will specify stainless steel, because it needs very little maintenance. We do not expect stainless steel to corrode easily. I would to ask the Senior Minister of State under which code where maintenance is specified so that it would not corrode. Otherwise, tomorrow, we would see a lot contractors would take the opportunity to say, "It corroded because you did not maintain it."

Well, I thank the Member for her input. Based on what I understand, stainless steel, again, requires maintenance. It is not totally maintenance free. If you go to very high grade of stainless steel, the maintenance is less frequent. Given that the LUP is an island-wide programme, we are working with a certain budget in mind. We should also be mindful of the fact that we should not over engineer the specifications so that the cost will go up and we cannot extend the coverage if LUP as wide as possible.

HDB has, in that instance, decided on stainless steel grade 430. It is still, nonetheless, stainless steel, but the grade is 430. But subsequently, it has reverted to grade 304 which so far, I think, has proven to be of a higher quality.
Ms Tin Pei Ling.

Thank you. I have two more questions for the Senior Minister of State. Firstly, for a new lift which is the main product of the LUP, would it be acceptable to expect that everything about the lift, including the lift frame and lift jamb, in this instance, to be rust-free? That is the first question. And the second question is now that it has already been installed and because the material has already been rusting for a while, and the Town Council has been required to maintain it, naturally, the manpower cost and material cost will go up more than perhaps in other precincts. Would there be any solution or proposal to help to defray some of these costs that the Town Council will now have to bear as a result of the quality of the stainless steel that was used in this particular LUP?

There are several terms used to describe the severity of the condition. One is "corrosion"; second is "rusting"; and the other one is "staining". If we are able to clean the lift frames, as they should be, let us say on a weekly or monthly basis, the staining can be removed quite easily without having it develop into rusting or corrosion of the steel. The maintenance regime can be incorporated into the regular cleaning schedule of the Town Councils, and, as I said, HDB will be happy to work with the respective Town Councils with such problems on finding ways to minimise the cleaning frequency.

asked  the Minister for Health (a) how many premature babies of pre-24 week gestational age are born annually in the last five years; (b) how many of these babies survived premature birth; and (c) whether the rate of survival of second trimester premature babies has improved significantly over the last decade.
(for the Minister for Health)

Among such premature babies born during 2008 to 2012, 48% survived beyond one year of age compared with 27% during the years 1998 to 2002. While the situation appears to have improved, given that the number of such babies is very small, we are unable to draw a definitive conclusion.

I would like to first thank the Senior Minister of State for assuring us that there has been an improvement in the survival rates for premature births. If the numbers continue to improve further down the line, it brings me to a fundamental question of whether the Ministry would also consider lowering the terms within the Termination of Pregnancy Act to reduce the term limit from 24 weeks to 20-23 weeks.

My second supplementary question relates to an announcement made earlier this year on public consultation for reviewing the guidelines on the termination of pregnancy as well as the proposal that all women seeking abortion should be counselled. Could the Senior Minister of State provide an update to the House as to the progress as well as the timeline for the consultation? I know that I have asked this on a number of occasions. So, I would ask the Senior Minister of State to indulge me.

I thank the Member for his supplementary questions. For the first question, to reiterate, the number of such preterm babies, as I have said earlier, is very small. So, we are unable to conclude with statistical confidence that there has been any real improvement in survival. In fact, this is also supported by international population- wide studies which showed that despite medical advancements in the care of preterm babies, there has not been a significant improvement in the survival rates of infants born before the 24-week time limit during the past decade. Twenty-four weeks gestational age continues to be generally regarded as a point of fetal viability, and this cut-off is, in fact, practised by countries like the United Kingdom, Japan and Australia. Locally, I would also like to note that only 2% of all abortions performed in 2013 were performed between the 21and 24 weeks of gestational age. Lowering the abortion limit would have little effect on lowering the overall abortion rates here.

Lastly, a routine fetal scan is performed at 20 weeks gestational age, and this is at the stage where the foetus is sufficiently developed to enable structural abnormalities to be picked up from the scan. In fact, more than half of the abortions performed between the 21st and 24th weeks of gestational age in 2013 were performed due to fetal anomalies or other medical reasons. Keeping the abortion limit at 24 weeks will allow these mothers some time to consider the implications and make an informed decision as to whether to keep or abort the child, without being rushed to meet a shorter cut-off time. In view of the lack of evidence to show that there are improvements in the survival of such extreme preterm babies, MOH is not considering the lowering of the abortion limit at this point in time.

Regarding the second question about the extension of pre-abortion counselling to all women seeking abortion in Singapore, we will be doing the public consultation by the end of this year. Review as to the contents of the pre-abortion counselling, the information to be provided during pre-abortion counselling and the training of the pre-abortion counsellors are also on-going, and details of these will be released once they are ready.

asked  the Minister for Transport (a) why are students receiving allowances from organisations ineligible for the Tertiary Student Concession Card; (b) what is the definition of such allowances; and (c) why are diploma students and undergraduates receiving scholarships or bursaries given on the basis of academic achievement or hardship not eligible for the Tertiary Student Concession Cards and why such a similar condition does not apply to students in the ITEs and junior colleges.
(for the Minister for Transport)

Having said that, the Council has asked the operators to consider extending student concessions to all full-time students in our ITEs, polytechnics and universities even if they are receiving some form of income, as the numbers are not large, and the distinction between them and other students who are receiving scholarships or bursary, is not always clear. The operators are considering the request.

Madam, I would like to clarify because based on the existing website, it makes a distinction between students from ITEs and junior colleges and students from the polytechnics and undergraduates. For those who are receiving scholarships or bursaries, one category is ineligible while one category qualifies for the concession. So I think there is a difference, in terms of the treatment, and I hope that the authority could normalise it, so that it is fair to all students studying in the various institutions.

Mdm Speaker, I should take this opportunity to clarify. In fact, ITE-sponsored students are treated the same way as sponsored students in the universities and polytechnics. They are also not eligible for student concessions today. However, there is an operational requirement for all ITE students to carry a "CEPAS" card for other functions, such as access within the school, TransitLink, which is the one that issues "CEPAS" cards, issues these cards to all these ITE students. So, it may appear that the ITE-sponsored students are treated differently from the sponsored students in polytechnics and universities. But, in fact, that is not the case. So, I just want to clarify that with the Member.
May I ask the Senior Minister of State, does it mean that ITE CEPAS card holders do not enjoy or do they enjoy travel concessions?

The ITE-sponsored students currently do not enjoy student concessions. Earlier in my reply, I have said that the Council had asked the operators to consider extending student concessions to all sponsored students who are in the institutions on a full-time basis. And if the operators were to agree to this, then it would apply equally to sponsored students in ITEs, universities and polytechnics.

asked  the Minister for Transport if he will provide an update on the Early Turnover Scheme (ETS) since its last enhancement in March 2014 in terms of (i) the number of vehicle owners who have benefited from ETS as compared to the period before the enhancement and (ii) the impact of ETS on the COE prices of commercial vehicles.
(for the Minister for Transport)

When an ETS-eligible vehicle is deregistered, its Certificate of Entitlement (COE) is not channelled to the Category (CAT) C quota for bidding. Rather, the COE can be used to register a new vehicle directly within a one-month period. This means that the owners can purchase a new vehicle without having to bid for a fresh COE.

Not channelling the COE of a deregistered ETS-eligible vehicle to the CAT C quota may appear on the surface to reduce the CAT C quota available for bidding. However, at the same time, it makes available an additional COE outside of the bidding system, and thus also takes demand out of the system as well. So we should not be unduly worried if there are low quotas available for bidding.
The ETS impact on COE price is uncertain. The price of COEs is determined by many other demand and supply factors, such as the prevailing economic conditions and the vehicle statutory life remaining.

Mdm Speaker, I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for the reply. I also like to congratulate the success of the ETS since its enhancement. But I also note that ETS in the market may not directly benefit the vehicle owners, but rather the agents. Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary can give us the figure on how many of the commercial vehicles that had been scrapped under the ETS have actually changed hands before scrapping. This figure would give us an indication whether the Early Turnover Scheme has benefited the car dealers as compared to the vehicle owners.

The second question is that I understand the ETS has reduced the number of COEs in Category C, but the Parliamentary Secretary is saying that it also takes demand out from the system. But this has a disadvantage for those companies that buy new commercial vehicles, without the old vehicles to take advantage of the ETS scheme. At the same time, we know that 15% of the COEs that are recycled from the deregistration of commercial vehicles are channelled towards the Open Category. Will MOT consider reducing the proportion of the COEs that can contribute to the Open Category?

Mdm Speaker, I thank the Member for the supplementary question. The ETS gives more options for current and would-be- vehicle owners to obtain a new vehicle  firstly, renew their existing COE under the ETS; secondly, to buy over a vehicle which is ETS-eligible, which then allows them to take advantage of the ETS to register a new vehicle; and thirdly, of course, to bid for a new COE. This, in my view, provides more opportunity for – those who would like to purchase vehicles, whether ETS-eligible or not. I do not have the figure of whether the vehicle is scrapped and is taken over by the dealers at this point in time. But those are the three options that someone who would like to purchase a vehicle would be able to do.

In addition to the ETS, commercial vehicles also have the benefits of lower vehicle taxes compared to other types of vehicles. The Additional Registration Fee, for example, is about 5% compared to at least 100% for cars.

asked the Prime Minister (a) in respect of public sector employees (including those from restructured hospitals) from middle-management downwards who have reached retirement age but are selected to be re-employed on a contract-basis, what safety nets are in place to protect such employees from diminution of their existing employment benefits solely on account of such re-employment; and (b) in what ways does the public sector intend to lead the private sector by example in promoting employment opportunities for people with disabilities. asked the Prime Minister (a) in respect of public sector employees (including those from restructured hospitals) from middle-management downwards who have reached retirement age but are selected to be re-employed on a contract-basis, what safety nets are in place to protect such employees from diminution of their existing employment benefits solely on account of such re-employment; and (b) in what ways does the public sector intend to lead the private sector by example in promoting employment opportunities for people with disabilities.
(for the Prime Minister)

Our approach is to offer re-employment to all officers who meet the performance and conduct criteria, and are medically fit to continue working. Since 1 July 2011, nine in 10 officers reaching the retirement age have been offered re-employment in the Civil Service. Agencies are urged to employ the majority of our officers in their existing jobs and at last drawn pay as far as possible. They are allowed to offer re-employment at lower grades for the more senior grades only if the post is no longer available or needs to be freed up to allow for leadership renewal.

To provide greater certainty for lower wage officers, since 1 August 2013, all Division III and IV officers are re-employed at the same substantive grade and last drawn salary. These guidelines have been worked out in close consultation with our unions.

Re-employment is a new episode of employment. Where benefits are concerned, all re-employed officers will be placed on the prevailing leave scheme with their years in service refreshed. Pensionable officers can choose to remain on their post-retirement medical benefit scheme or take up the prevailing Medisave-cum Subsidised Outpatient (MSO) scheme. Non-pensionable officers without post-retirement medical benefits will be placed on the prevailing MSO scheme. As we have announced recently, the Public Service will take the lead to extend our re-employment age to 67 from 1 January 2015, so that more officers can benefit from re-employment. This is also in line with the Tripartite Committee's recommendations.

Re-structured hospitals, which the Member has asked about, are private entities with their own benefit schemes that would have considered the aforementioned Tripartite Guidelines as well, when they consider re-employment for their employees.

The second part of Ms Chia's question is not directly related to the first part. Recruitment into the Public Service is based on individual merit, through fair and open competition. We do employ officers with disabilities in the service and are prepared to do more. The Public Service Division is working with the Ministry of Social and Family Development to see how we can help agencies hire and tap on the diverse abilities of persons with disabilities.

I thank the Deputy Prime Minister for his clarifications. I have two supplementary questions. First, in relation to the re-employment issue, I would like to ask if the Government can give the assurance that the job scope and the benefits will not be re-scoped solely on pecuniary grounds based on budgetary considerations.

In relation to the Deputy Prime Minister's clarification on the second point, I do understand that employment is on a merit basis, nonetheless as we encourage private sector employers to employ and to be flexible in job scope, in job re-design and hours, I would like to ask what steps the public sector would be taking to lead the private sector in this respect.

Mdm Speaker, on the first comment that the Member made, I explained already the basis on which re-employment offers are made in the public sector and those are the factors which are taken into consideration.

On the issue of employment of persons with disabilities, the Public Service Division is working with SG Enable and the MSF to see how we can do a number of the things which the Member has suggested, and to see how we can employ more persons with disabilities and even restructure some of the jobs to make them more accessible.

I am heartened that the Government has taken the lead to extend the re-employment age to 67 years. My supplementary question is that although I am glad to note that nine out of 10 are offered re-employment in the public service, I would like to know what assistance is given to public service employees who are able and want to continue working but are not re-employed in the public service. And my last question is will the public service also take the lead in re-engineering the workplace so that older workers can stay employed longer and be more productive as well. What are some of the initiatives undertaken by the public service, if any?

Mdm Speaker, we have offered re-employment to nine out of 10 of our officers who reach retirement age. I think it is not a bad number. There are reasons why some of the officers are not re-employed. They may not be medically fit. They may not have good service records and so we should not expect 100% because there are considerations which every employer will have to take into account when offering re-employment.

For those officers who are eligible for re-employment, but are not offered re-employment, the public sector does assist them to find alternative avenues for employment and where there is not possible, there is also a system, according to the guidelines of the Tripartite Committee, to provide them with some ex gratia payment to help them.

asked  the Minister for Social and Family Development (a) under what circumstances will the Ministry get directly involved in care-giving arrangements for a child where his parent, guardian or caregiver has been diagnosed with mental illness and has a history of violent behaviour; (b) whether the Ministry will provide arrangements for the child to be under state care in order to protect his safety; and (c) how many of such cases has the Ministry handled over the last five years.

Mdm Speaker, MSF takes a serious view of each referred case that raises concerns over a child's safety. We conduct investigations to assess the risks posed to the child's safety, the needs of the child and family, and work out an appropriate intervention plan for the family.

Depending on the circumstances of the case, the child may be able to remain in the parents' care, with safety plans and support services in place or if an alternative care arrangement is necessary, we will first explore kinship care, followed by foster care and as a last resort, placement in a residential home. Each year, of all cases referred to MSF for investigation, about 10% or fewer than 20 cases involved parents or caregivers with mental illness and violent behaviour.

Not all cases are referred or known to the Ministry. There are potentially vulnerable cases in the community whom we would like to extend support to. This is where we hope the community can play a part to help us to reach out to these families. We can all stay vigilant and alert the authorities if we come across any children in vulnerable circumstances.

Families facing stress can also seek help early by visiting the nearest Family Service Centre or Social Service Office. As the issues can be complex, we need the collaboration of different stakeholders and professionals to provide multi-dimensional support for these families.
Dr Janil.

Thank you, Mdm Speaker. I have two supplementary questions for the Minister. When a child or any vulnerable person who is known to the Ministry or any other agencies, suffers an injury or unfortunate death, is there a need for a formal review process or inquiry? Some jurisdictions have Standing Committees or confidential inquiries where any death or injury to a vulnerable person is automatically investigated to identify systemic issues, especially those that exist between agencies. Would the Minister consider that there is a need for this in our circumstances?

My second supplementary question  in terms of separating a child from a family, it is necessarily a very difficult decision to make, and the bar is appropriately set high. My question is to what extent are resource constraints a factor in this consideration? In particular, do we have sufficient resources for fostering? Do we have enough families that are stepping forward or volunteering themselves for foster care and is there anything we can do to make available that path to provide an appropriate home and a place for safety for these vulnerable children?

Mdm Speaker, with reference to the first question, yes, there is indeed a formal review process should any children under our care come into harm's way or should there be an unfortunate incident where a death occurs. But there are two separate processes. One is for cases that are known to us but not under the Child Protection Service. And the other one has to do with children under our care and that could include children under residential care.

In both scenarios, in any incident where anything untoward happens to the young child, we would initiate a review process like what the Member has suggested. We will look through our own processes to see where we can tighten, or where there might have been lapses, we will take action accordingly. So, there are processes in place whenever such an unfortunate incident happens. For us, we take each and every case very seriously because whether the child is directly under the charge of the Child Protection Service or is under one of our programmes, we would always want all the stakeholders to come together to look at the case again to see how we can do better, especially when the child suffers an injury. We would want to see how we can protect the child and prevent this from happening again.

On the second question about the separation of the child from their family – indeed, we agree with the Member that it is always very difficult and painful for us to have to take a child away from the family. That is why when we look at the cases and do the case conference for each and every individual case, we do what we call, a triage system whereby we have the three levels of care arrangement.

The first level of care arrangement is, as far as possible, for the child to continue to stay with the immediate family or one of his kin. We believe that in such an environment, the child is best able to re-integrate with his immediate family, rehabilitate and re-establish the family ties where possible.

In the event that we are unable to have the child placed in a relative's home, or an immediate family member's home, the second tier would be foster-care. Again, we believe that this is still better than a residential or institutional environment because this provides a more natural environment for the child to grow up and be re-integrated into the community.

As a final resort, if we do not have family support and, are unable to find a suitable foster parent for the child, we will put the child into an institutional home. But even at this stage, we will be constantly looking out for opportunities to re-integrate the child with the family or if not, to bring the child to a suitable foster family for him or her to grow up in a more homely environment.

I do not think at this point in time resources have been a constraint. However, we would like to encourage more families to come forward to provide foster care for the children. I have recently made known at the 25th Anniversary of the Muhammadiyah Welfare Home that we are indeed looking at more families coming forward to join the Foster Parents Scheme. Even if a new foster family cannot take on the responsibility immediately, we are exploring ways to induct the family progressively into the Foster Parents Scheme, and also to help the child build up the relationship progressively with the foster parent family.

Like in many other countries, we have found that the results for the child is more positive if we are able to encourage the child to stay in a homely environment in the community rather than a residential or institutional environment, which is always artificial at its best.

asked  the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs whether the Police can take on a more active role in investigating complaints against timeshare companies as criminal offences under cheating rather than leaving it to aggrieved customers to bring civil claims at their own cost.
(for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs)

The number of police reports lodged against timeshare companies averaged 110 per year over the last five years. Police have initiated investigations into about half of these reported cases. This has resulted in investigations into 11 groups of timeshare companies in the past five years. In one of the cases that is still in Court, the accused has been charged with 72 counts of cheating under section 420 of the Penal Code.

Police take a serious view of persons or companies misleading or deceiving unsuspecting consumers into making sham purchases. However, gathering evidence is challenging and can take a long time as many errant timeshare companies are incorporated overseas. Masterminds may also use false names to run the companies.

Police will continue to work with the Consumers Association of Singapore (CASE) and media partners to alert the general public and potential consumers of any emerging timeshare scams. The regulations of the Consumer Protection (Fair Trading) Act (CPFTA) that protect consumers against errant timeshare companies were revised earlier this year to provide consumers with greater protection and flexibility and encourage timeshare companies to review their products and services. Under the CPFTA, CASE may obtain injunction orders against errant traders for unfair practices such as misleading claims and pressure selling.

On the consumers' part, they must remain vigilant and do their due diligence before signing any contract with timeshare companies. Consumers should check for information on their obligations and their rights to cancel the contract, which timeshare companies are required to provide before any contract is signed. Attention should also be paid to the fine print and hidden costs so that an informed decision can be made. In cases involving breaches of contract conditions, aggrieved consumers will need to seek recourse through civil means.

I thank the Minister for his response. The Minister mentioned that half of the average of 110 per year were deemed to be criminal offences and at least investigated at such. May I enquire of the Minister about the other half  was it the Police's view that no dishonesty was involved on the part of the timeshare providers? Why I ask this question, Madam, is because in my constituency, I have had situations where elderly have been cheated, have been misrepresented to, and from what I can see of the evidence, there was dishonesty. However, the Police took the view that that ought to have been a civil recourse case. My question really is, if there is dishonesty and dishonesty is represented, and a consumer acts on that dishonesty mistakenly, would that be rightfully categorised as a cheating offence?

Madam, I thank the good Member for his question. I want to stress that, essentially, the process is such that when a complaint is received, the Police have to conduct inquiries to first ascertain whether there is sufficient basis to infer that an offence is potentially disclosed, before they then proceed into detailed investigations. So,for the kind of circumstances that the Member has described, it really turns on the specifics of individual cases and then the Police's inquiries, and the assessment arising from those inquiries.

As I have mentioned earlier, some of the challenges here also lie in the fact that the nature of these activities is such that it is not easy to obtain all the information. So, whilst an individual may feel that he has been misled, proving that, as the Member would well appreciate, can be challenging.

Having said that, if the Member has particular points to raise regarding specific cases, I think he can surface them and we can ask the Police to look at them again. But, in general, that is the process, and then we have also strengthened the legislation under the consumer protection component. We have provided for recourse for specific bodies to take up injunctions where there is evidence as well.

A supplementary question. Would the Minister encourage the Police to red-flag cases where elderly victims are concerned and large amounts of money have actually been released to timeshare companies? Would the combination of those two facts give rise to special considerations where investigation is concerned?

Mdm Speaker, I am not sure what the Member means by red-flagging. If by that he means making it generally well-known and raising public awareness that there are cases such as these, then that is where the overall public education effort comes in, which the Police undertake together with the Consumers Association and others. I think this is a very important component.
Where an offence is disclosed, and if it pertains to the elderly or otherwise, I think those sorts of cases will also have to be publicised as part of the larger education effort.

But we have to bear in mind that we have to be fair to the other side of the equation, which is the companies as well. Because until an offence is in fact disclosed and proven, we also have to be careful in the way we go about the enforcement activities. That is the balance that should be struck. But I take the point of the Member on the whole issue of raising awareness and making sure that for vulnerable consumers, in particular, we do our best to alert them to the possible risks of undertaking such transactions.

asked  the Minister for Trade and Industry if he will provide an update on the Comprehensive Economic Co-operation Agreement (CECA) negotiations and, specifically, whether India is entitled to special access to Singapore's labour market or banking licences under the terms of CECA.

Mdm Speaker, the India-Singapore Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) entered into force on 1 August 2005. CECA provides for reviews to examine issues related to the Agreement. The first review was completed in 2007 and the second review is on-going.

CECA has increased trade and investment flows between India and Singapore. Bilateral trade grew from S$16.6 billion in 2005 to S$25.5 billion in 2013. Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) from India into Singapore grew from S$1.3 billion in 2005 to S$20 billion in 2012. This has helped to create good jobs for Singaporeans.

CECA serves to bring conveniences to businesses by allowing temporary entry on both sides for certain categories of persons, including business visitors, professionals, and Intra-Corporate Transferees.

Under CECA, Singapore agreed to grant three bank licences with Qualifying Full Bank (QFB) privileges to Indian banks, subject to the prudential requirements of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Two Indian QFBs, namely State Bank of India and ICICI Bank, have been approved to date. At the same time, India agreed to allow the three Singapore banks to open a total of 15 bank branches in India and 11 branches have been approved so far.

I have two supplementary questions, Madam. I understand that India is claiming that our Work Pass framework, which has been tightened in recent years, somehow violates CECA, or they are saying that they are entitled to allow more workers to come in here. So, can the Minister share with us his interpretation of what India's claims are?

Secondly, can the Minister also share Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI)'s position on this, and also give us an assurance that the Government will stand up to pressure from the Indians to allow more of their nationals to work here?

Under the Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) that we negotiated, there is an exchange of preferential treatment. In India's case, in CECA's case, one of the privileges we extend to India was to create greater conveniences for business people to move between the two countries, Singaporean businessmen to India, and vice versa.

One category is Intra-Corporate Transferees. That means if you got employees that you have employed and you are setting up a business in Singapore, we facilitate the transfer of your corporate employees to help you set up and run the business.

Under the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) in World Trade Organization (WTO), we grant such Intra-Corporate Transferees, say five years. In India's case, we allow them to do so for eight years. These are the kind of privileges.

All these privileges do not deviate from our right to apply measures to regulate the entry as well as a temporary stay. So, the overall immigration and employment rules that we regulate have to be maintained. But where the special privileges are negotiated in the FTA, then, of course, the counter-party will enjoy those privileges. And we will follow these rules strictly.

Madam, I understand the point about the privileges. My question is, are we granting them all the privileges that they are entitled to under the CECA, or are they saying that we are not granting them enough? If it is the latter, would that mean that, effectively, the Indians are asking for more Work Passes for themselves?

The privileges are clearly delineated in the FTAs and in CECA. As I had explained just now, say, for example, Intra-Corporate Transferees, if the Indians dispute that we are not giving them eight years as we agreed, then they can refer the case to us and, ultimately, there is a dispute settlement process.

asked  the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) to what extent businesses in the accommodation and food services industry are affected by the recent spike in its job vacancy rate; (b) whether there had been any impact on the recently concluded F1 Singapore Grand Prix event; and (c) whether there is any interim assessment about the success with which businesses such as hotels and restaurants are making the transition to the tighter manpower supply.
(for the Minister for Trade and Industry)

Notwithstanding this, hotels continued to maintain a steady Average Occupancy Rate and Revenue per Available Room (RevPar) of 86% and S$219 respectively for January to July 2014. Hotel occupancy rates also held steady during the recent F1 Singapore Grand Prix compared to the 2013 race.

While economic restructuring has been painful for companies such as hotels and restaurants, there has been some initial success. Real productivity for Accommodation and Food Services grew by 0.9% per year between 2010 and 2013. Labour productivity for the Accommodation sector has picked up with the opening of new tourism offerings since 2010, improving by 2.8% per year from 2010 to 2013, as compared to a historical 0.6% per year from 2004 to 2009. Likewise, the labour productivity for the Food Services sector improved to -0.6% per year from 2010 to 2013, against a historical rate of -3.4% per year from 2004 to 2009.

We are also seeing good adoption of productivity initiatives by businesses within the Food Services sector. For example, SPRING has supported 644 projects to date under the Food Services roadmap including key initiatives like workflow re-design, adoption of technology, kitchen automation and service excellence.

One company that has successfully incorporated digital service in its existing concepts is Gloria Foods. Gloria Foods installed digital service ordering and payment kiosk in its Baja Fresh Mexican Grill outlet at Rendezvous Gallery. Customers can now place their orders through the interactive touch-screen menu and make payment through digital service kiosk. Besides cutting the average waiting time by three to five minutes, the system also reduces wrong orders and minimises mismanagement of cash.

Let me give you another example from the Hotels industry  Shangri-La's Rasa Sentosa & Spa Singapore. They have consolidated its kitchen teams into one central kitchen for greater productivity. The hotel is also sharing common functions such as payroll, credit, purchasing, laundry, pastry, et cetera, with its sister hotels within the Shangri-La Group. Furthermore, the hotel reviewed and re-designed its menu and dining concepts to reduce the number of cooks and chefs in the kitchen. In all, the hotel reduced its overall staff strength by about 10% from 2012 to 2014. And you can also find other examples of such productivity and innovation case studies on Singapore Tourism Board's (STB) website under the Hotel Industry Story-Bank.

While we have made progress in our restructuring efforts, there is more that we need to do. The Government will continue to closely monitor how businesses adjust to the tight labour market situation. We will continue to help businesses within the Accommodation and Food Services sector to grow and succeed in Singapore to create quality jobs for Singaporeans.

I would like to thank the Minister of State for his very comprehensive reply. I am also very encouraged by the reassurance that our productivity record is slowly but surely improving. I would like to ask a supplementary question specifically about the large-scale Singapore Grand Prix night race that we have been successfully hosting for about seven years now, if I recall correctly.

Given the size and scale of such a prominent event, the performance of our service sector in being able to host such a significant event should provide us with further information about how it is reacting to the tightening of the labour market constraints. One of the reasons I think this is important is because the tightening of the labour market constraints is going to be worse for some time to come.

If I recall the statistics correctly, the tightening in the job vacancy ratio for the accommodation and food sector actually spiked in the September quarter last year. What that means is that we will have seen two of the more recent F1 races operating under the tighter manpower constraints. I know the manpower constraints have been tight for quite some time now. But it appears that the job vacancy rates have already spiked for the last two races. Is there any specific reaction for such a major event to this particular phenomenon?

The latest numbers I have got, as I had mentioned earlier, was 6% in the second quarter of 2014, compared to 4.4% a year ago. From the ground sentiments and from talks the trade associations, we also understand that some of the businesses, SMEs and so on are facing some challenges. Definitely, it is a journey and it is a long haul journey to actually transform and make changes to become more productive and automate the processes. It is not going to be easy.

As we monitor the situation, we know that some of the companies will do it better than others. We will continue to encourage by providing some of the schemes and grants to help them make the change. It is up to the companies themselves to be able to do so.

The general sentiment is that they are still facing some manpower challenges because it takes time to make the change. But for events like F1 and some of these large-scale events, we are still able to manage them; we are still able to host them with a good quality service level. So far, the latest one that was held, we have got very positive feedback in terms of services, in terms of companies providing contract work, food and beverage and hosting the whole event. Progressively, we are making leaps and bounds in terms of productivity as well as the kind of quality service that we provide throughout the F1 event.
We will monitor and definitely MOM and ourselves are also working hard and looking at the numbers. We also look at the companies and are working with trade associations to do so.

asked  the Minister for Transport with the introduction of free Wifi services at select MRT stations (a) what is the outcome of the trial; and (b) when will this service be extended to Khatib MRT station which has a high volume of commuters.

(for the Minister for Transport) Madam, the WIFI@MRT trial was launched on 22 August 2014 at City Hall, Orchard and Raffles Place MRT station platforms. It has been well-received. More than 100,000 commuters used the free WIFI service on the first day, and this has steadily increased to more than 145,000 users today. The WIFI@MRT service will be made available at Khatib MRT station by next year.

I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for his reply. I am not going to ask for just Choa Chu Kang station. I am going to ask in terms of roll-out plans. How do you plan to deploy from the town centres, all the way up to Khatib and the rest?

Madam, Mr Zaqy asked a very reasonable question. I must say that it is a trial period, lasting two years. And we are focusing our efforts, and we start with the interchange stations, including Choa Chu Kang and also stations where there are high volumes of commuters. If we find it well received and Singaporeans like it and use it, I think ultimately we will roll out to the rest of the MRT stations.

Beyond that, we are looking at how we can enhance the travel experience of Singaporeans. LTA is assessing how we can also provide Wifi services on buses, in the interchange, as well as, as I said earlier, at more MRT stations.
Er Lee Bee Wah, are you asking for something else?

Thank you, Parliamentary Secretary. I am glad to hear that by next year commuters at Khatib MRT station will be able to use the free Wifi. I would like to ask which month next year. Is it January next year or is it December next year? Which month?
Madam, we have plans for Khatib. And I think at the end of the day, Khatib is one of the stations that has high commuter traffic. I think it will be one of the priority stations next year.
I think you have opened a Pandora box. Mr David Ong.

I want to thank the Parliamentary Secretary for his response that more stations will be Wifi ready and hopefully it will be nation-wide. I think it is a given that all of us would need it. So, I would hope that you could roll out Wifi in all the MRT stations, as commuters will have a need for it.

The Member has made a good point, Madam. Nevertheless, we want to make sure that we roll out in a manner that will be able to reach out to many people without much of a hiccup. Today we are testing out the whole process. It has been well-received. Nevertheless, we want to see how we can facilitate it better. So, I assure him we are seriously looking into it because at the end of the day, we are committed to enhance the travel experience of our commuters.

asked  the Minister for Transport whether LTA will consider using technology to equip (i) bus stops with audible announcements of arriving bus service numbers; and (ii) buses with on-board announcements of approaching bus stops to better enable visually-impaired commuters to travel more independently, safely and conveniently.
(for the Minister for Transport)

Mdm Speaker, LTA is already in the process of developing a central bus management system which will be capable of relaying real-time information to and from buses and bus stops. This system will be implemented progressively from end-2015 and completed in 2017. At that time, we will have announcements of the next bus stop, for example broadcasted on buses, or delivered in a more targeted way through smart-phone applications and other devices. Today, however, the bus operators have separate fleet management systems and do not have the necessary infrastructure and systems in place to support such announcements.
In the meantime, LTA will continue to work with the bus operators to ensure that bus captains are trained to offer persons with disabilities the assistance they need to travel safely and reliably.

I really appreciate the assurance by the Senior Minister of State that this system would be rolled out. Can I clarify that with this new fleet management system, it will mean that there will be audible announcements on all buses and will that extend to the bus stops as well to announce the incoming buses so that the visually-impaired commuters will be notified of the incoming buses.

Mdm Speaker, the Member's clarification is a useful one. Audible announcements being broadcasted on buses is fairly straightforward because only the people in the buses will hear them and so it does not cause much disturbance. For audible announcements at bus stops, it is something that we have to consider more carefully. The reason being that some of the bus stops are located quite near to people's homes. At busy times of the day where the buses are arriving at a bus stop, sometimes on a continuous basis, can you imagine what it means for people who are living in homes quite near these bus stops?

That is something that we have to look at quite carefully. Now, there are only a very small number of cities in the world that have attempted audible announcements at bus stops and where they have done so, it has not been comprehensively implemented. There are only selected bus stops where they will introduce these audible announcements. What we also know is that typically the preference is for push button, on-demand type of announcements so that visually-impaired persons if they require these announcements can access them. However, these announcements are not made at all times of the day and as and when every single bus arrives.

Those are some of the issues that we will have to look into. But, as I said earlier, in today's context the infrastructure and systems are not even in place to support such audible announcements at bus stops. We will have to let this new system be implemented and then we will at the same time look at how audible announcements can be made feasible at bus stops as well as on buses.

I thank the Senior Minister of State again for the reply. Is it technically impossible to do it or is it just the noise problem? Because I believe all the SMRT bus stops already have visual announcements of the incoming buses. So I do not see why that technology cannot be extended to audible announcements.

Secondly, I do not think the announcement needs to be that loud because visually-impaired commuters would tend to have more sensitive hearing so it does not have to be so loud that it disturbs the residents nearby. And, perhaps, the Ministry could consider some other alternatives. One is to have tactile announcements that use touch rather than sound to announce the incoming buses.

Thirdly, I think what some cities do is that the buses themselves have an announcement when it pulls into the bus stop to inform the commuters about what bus number that is. From my conversations with the members of the visually-impaired community this is a more pressing need than the announcements on board the bus. They could be at an empty bus stop and not have anyone to ask what the next bus number is. They have told me that even when the bus arrives and they ask the bus driver, sometimes the bus driver just gives a nod or shakes his head. So, to the visually-impaired commuter there is no response. I hope the Ministry can look into this. Thank you.
We certainly will. Thank you.

I would to ask the Senior Minister of State since we are buying a new fleet of buses, can we order the buses in such a way that the door is right at the back, so that commuters when they move into the bus, will move towards the back of the bus straightaway? I think the design of the bus will help commuters in moving towards the back of the bus.
Mdm Speaker, I do not see how this has got to do with audible announcements but we thank her for her suggestion. We will take a look at that.

asked the Minister for Social and Family Development whether there are plans for the Early Childhood Development Agency or any other agency to develop competencies of teachers in the Early Intervention Programmes for Infants and Children (EIPIC) and other programmes that support teachers working in pre-school settings. asked the Minister for Social and Family Development whether there are plans for the Early Childhood Development Agency or any other agency to develop competencies of teachers in the Early Intervention Programmes for Infants and Children (EIPIC) and other programmes that support teachers working in pre-school settings.

Mdm Speaker, from 1 October this year, EIPIC teachers are required to attend certified training in early intervention within two years of joining the sector. The courses include Ngee Ann Polytechnic's two-year part-time Advanced Diploma in Early Childhood Intervention for Special Needs and certificate courses run by the Autism Resource Centre. Eighty per cent of the course fee is covered by subsidies from the VWOs Capability Fund.

The Development Support Programme (DSP) supports children in mainstream pre-schools with mild learning difficulties. An eight-month course is in place to train the Learning Support Educators to equip them to screen the children and to carry out in-class support.

In addition to these efforts, the Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA) will support pre-school educators to develop deeper professional competencies and skills by putting in place structured career pathways for the early childhood sector. Opportunities for upgrading are also being expanded through a Continuing Professional Development (CPD) Masterplan, which has seen over 5,000 teachers trained this year. More CPD courses will be added next year, which will include courses that help teachers identify and support children with special needs.

I thank the Minister for his reply. Thank you, Madam, for this opportunity to ask a supplementary question. Given the lag time in the training and the fact that we do have a number of children who require assistance and development intervention, I would like to ask the Minister if his Ministry and the Ministry of Manpower would favourably consider the recruitment of suitably qualified foreigners and the retention of those who are already employed here. I thank the Minister for his reply. Thank you, Madam, for this opportunity to ask a supplementary question. Given the lag time in the training and the fact that we do have a number of children who require assistance and development intervention, I would like to ask the Minister if his Ministry and the Ministry of Manpower would favourably consider the recruitment of suitably qualified foreigners and the retention of those who are already employed here.

The answer is "yes". We are closely working with MOM to see how we can expand the pool of teachers trained in this speciality and that includes the possibility of looking for foreign trained teachers.

Just to pick up on the point on the Development Support Programme (DSP). I understand that the DSP is rolled out only in certain pre-schools for K1 and K2 students. Are there plans to expand it to all pre-schools? And are there also plans to extend the EIPIC programme to more centres?

Mdm Speaker, let me answer the second question on EIPIC first. Yes, indeed, we are in the process of expanding the capacity for EIPIC. Over the last few years, we have upped the capacity to about 2,300. By 2015, we should see it going up to about 2,700. We will continually assess the needs for such services as we do better in early intervention and diagnosis for young children.

For the first question on the Development Support Programme, we will expand the programme according to the needs of the sector. But I must say at this point in time that we are also taking a review of how we organise the entire sector to provide support for children with special needs. And that is because we have two contrasting models possible. One is to have special childcare centres where all the children with special needs are concentrated together. This, arguably, is efficient; but from a social mixing point of view may not be optimal. On the other hand, we have another model which is to integrate all the children with special needs into the programmes for all the other normal children. This is, arguably, more resource intensive. It stretches the teachers a lot because in each of those centres, we need to have dedicated teachers who are able to do those programmes with the children. But arguably, from a social integration point of view, that is a better outcome.

Between these two contrasting models, we have to find the balancing point between what we are able to do with what is optimal from a social integration viewpoint. And my Ministry will continue to look at this issue closely.
Ms Denise Phua.

Thank you, Madam. I would like to ask the Minister if he would consider this other model which is right in the middle of what was explained by him. It is between the segregation model where special needs children are all huddled together in one physical location and the other one where the children are fully mainstreamed.

There are models in the world that actually middle-of-the-ground models where there are for example, special schools within schools, or early intervention centres within a mainstream pre-school setting. That is something that is not uncommon now. I would like to ask the Minister if he would consider studying that. Some of us who were serving in the special needs sector would be very happy to help out in the solutioning.

Mdm Speaker, yes, indeed that is one of the ideas that we are exploring to balance what I have just described as the two extreme models. Somewhere in between whereby we have a certain critical mass of special needs students at the same place to allow the resources to be used more efficiently; yet, at the same time, integrated with some of the programmes from the mainstream school.

This will require us to do better upfront planning in terms of infrastructure support so that the two set-ups can be integrated together. And this is something that we will certainly explore going forward and we welcome Ms Denise Phua's help and suggestions to mobilise the community for us to see how we can bring this together. Because that would help us to better achieve the outcomes in terms of social integration and also resource utilisation which is also a real challenge for the sector.

asked  the Minister for National Development (a) if he can update the House on the outcome of HDB's study on the option of reverse mortgages for elderly HDB flat owners; and (b) how will the scheme work out for elderly flat owners.

Madam, a reverse mortgage is a loan taken up by a property owner using his property as collateral. However, unlike a traditional mortgage, the borrower need not make any cash repayment during the loan tenure. Instead, he only needs to repay the loan with accumulated interest upon termination or upon death, typically from the sales proceeds. A reverse mortgage thus allows the property owner to unlock some equity while retaining the financial upside from any appreciation in property value in a rising market.

However, reverse mortgage has its risks. First, as it does not require periodic cash repayments, the loan balance grows with interest. Second, the owner has to bear property risks. If the market value of the property becomes less than the outstanding loan, the owner may have to sell the property to repay the loan.
In 2006, NTUC Income offered reverse mortgage for HDB flats. Only 24 households signed up and NTUC Income has since stopped offering the product.

Nevertheless, MND is revisiting the subject. We are studying several countries with established reverse mortgage plans, and to learn from their experiences. But we note that these countries are also finding their take-up rates to be quite low. As the reverse mortgage is a complex financial product, we need to study it carefully, consult our people, before we decide whether to introduce it as an additional option for our seniors.

I thank the Minister for his update on the developments. Certainly, I think today we have got the Lease Buyback Scheme already in place. What is MND's strategy in terms of pursuing both the Lease Buyback (LBS) as well as reverse mortgage? To the ordinary citizens, I do not think they might be able to differentiate the two. And is there a concerted strategy that we are embarking on both paths?

Indeed, the two products are different and we are not embarking on both. We are only right now offering LBS. But we are studying reverse mortgage just to see whether it will be viable, although it has been tried before, but whether between 2006 and now, have there been changes in the business model that we can learn from, and where we may find that the new product offering might be suitable for some clientele.

Our objective is to offer a range of options. So it is not wrong if we were to decide to offer both. Then individuals would have options to choose which one will suit them better. For some, they may find Lease Buyback attractive; others may find reverse mortgage more suitable.

The key is informed decision making which means very close hand-holding and if we were to offer such products, our staff would have to be well-trained so that they can conduct individual counselling. Get down to specifics -- your flat, in what address, what is the indicative market price, how much proceeds can you get if you were to do Lease Buyback; if you do reverse mortgage, what does it mean and what are the implications. These are, as I said before long-term commitments, 30 or 40 years down the road. We want to make sure that people make up their minds with all the information at hand.

Mdm Speaker, I think reverse mortgage is just one of the various options available for residents to choose from and it has been in discussion recently. I would like to ask the Minister, in the Ministry's study of other countries, what are the challenges that you have come across? Perhaps, you can share with the House.
Usually, I try to reply fully to Er Dr Lee Bee Wah. But on this instance, I cannot because this study is still on-going.

It is work in progress and the preliminary feedback to me is, even in many of these countries or cities, the take-up rates are really low. In other words, not particularly encouraging. We are not aware of any country where reverse mortgage is extensively taken up or has seen wide usage.

I am not giving up and we want to continue to explore. But I do not want to raise hope too that we will definitely do reverse mortgage. The fact that take-up rates are low, not only in Singapore but elsewhere must suggest that the providers and the people probably find it unattractive. In fact, today, there are no regulatory impediments against any of our financial institutions from offering reverse mortgage for private properties, for example. They can offer it. In fact, a couple offered it a few years back and they also faced the same problems as what NTUC Income did. They then stopped offering the product.

So, obviously, the market is probably not ripe yet. There are many ways to interpret it. I tend to interpret it positively to mean that the owners, our seniors, have additional savings or I would like to believe that many families have good children. And the good children are providing monthly allowances to their parents which I think will be lovely. And therefore, the parents do not see a need for wanting to exercise these various monetisation options.

As I said in this House a couple of sessions ago, to me, the best outcome is the parents move in at the invitation of their kids, to be with the kids and then they whilst still own their own flat, rent it out, whole flat and collect easily more than $1,000 or $1,500 per month in rental. That is the best outcome for most, if not all Singaporean families.
